summary: William K. Harvey was a CIA personnel member, as indicated by multiple documents. He was assigned to the Berlin Base, according to Robert Glenn Thompson's recollection from his time with OSI, Berlin. Documents also detail his retirement from the CIA, personnel actions, salary adjustments, and his issuance of Federal Aviation Agency Credential Number 4883. He was interviewed by David W. Belin concerning his background and knowledge of assassination plots within the CIA. He also testified in 1975 regarding Operation ZRRIFLE, focusing on recruitment, development, and security protocols for clandestine agents. FBI interviews in March 1963 touched on CIA efforts to penetrate the USSR and details about the Technical Aids Detachment (TAD) in Frankfurt, Germany. An FBI report also indicates that Robert Glenn Thompson provided information about Harvey to the Soviets.
significance: William K. Harvey's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his involvement in clandestine operations and assassination plots within the CIA, as indicated by his interview with David W. Belin and his testimony regarding Operation ZRRIFLE. The documents suggest he had knowledge of sensitive information and was a key figure in covert activities during that period.
